title.narrative: No News is Bad News - Zimbabwe

description.narrative: CONTEXT ANALYSIS: Zimbabwe has seen the biggest political change in nearly four decades, with longtime ruler Robert Mugabe resigning on November 21 after his own party, ZANU-PF started proceedings to impeach him while the military took over control of the country and placed him under house arrest in a de facto coup. Emmerson Mnangagwa, Mugabe’s long-time aide who he had dismissed as his deputy on November 6, was nominated to take over as party and government leader, to complete his term of office and stand the ruling party’s candidate in the elections in 2018. Mugabe’s fall was preceded by increased levels of political unrest, which escalated since April 2016, after a video by a local pastor went viral and sparked a chain reaction across the country. In just a short time, massive civil unrest displayed online grew into a national movement offline, the so-called #ThisFlag movement. By July that year, movement leaders managed to successfully organise a national shutdown, followed by other peaceful protests across the country. The government responded by retaliating with violence. Journalists and other civil society activists run high risks of being arrested without charges or physically assaulted. Protests were banned, although the High Court proclaimed the protests legal and constitutional. The new president has promised a raft of changes since he took office, including a return to the rule of law and respect for property rights as well as constitutionally allowed human rights. The president is under pressure from civic society, would-be investors and opposition parties to implement political and economic reforms as the country is due to hold elections by July 2018 in the first big test of his legitimacy. Under Mugabe, Zimbabwe was among the world’s most censored countries with a raft of laws to muzzle or restrict the few independent media that existed. Even then, they often were physically attacked, jailed and faced persistent harassment. According to the Media Institute for Southern Africa (Misa), between 2017 and 2017, there have been 32 instances in which journalists had been assaulted or harassed while doing their jobs. The new president has so far not exhibited extremist behaviour and has sought to engage with the media and the public via interviews with mainly international media, and social media. He has promised to respect democratic rights but has hardly mentioned human rights or media rights. One can only hope that those rights will include media freedom and that the government will remove laws that have been used a free media environment. He has done nothing yet, however, to remove or reduce the plenty mechanisms for controlling the media in Zimbabwe that were put in place by Mugabe. These mechanisms include the new Ministry of Information Communication Technology and Cyber Security as well as the country’s so-called “access to information” law, which includes the powerful Media and Information Commission regulatory body. Zimbabwe is classified as a low-income country; ranked 155 out of 188 countries in the Human Development Index. PROBLEM ANALYSIS: Zimbabwe's press freedom declined and is currently ranked 162nd and as 'not free' in the 2016 Freedom of the Press Index. Although freedom of expression and press freedom are protected in the 2013 constitution, in practice these rights are curbed and stifled by the Access to Information and Protection of Privacy Act (AIPPA) and the Public Order and Security Act (POSA). Under POSA, public demonstrations and protests are effectively illegal. AIPPA stifles freedom of expression and criminalises defamation and libel. The Majority of Zimbabwe's media is owned or controlled by the state. Zimbabwe's media landscape and sector remains highly polarised. Print media sector is the most developed sector, yet very small, with few independent players who have difficulty securing readers outside of the 2 main cities (Harare and Bulawayo). Its radio and television sector is predominantly state-owned despite some newcomers in the radio sector. Due to this situation, there are no truly independent local and licensed radio or TV stations. Those that can be called independent, including EJC's The Source, depend largely on donor funding, which has been declining since 2013. Journalism education is of poor quality and lacks necessary equipment. Journalism graduates lack both theoretical as well as practical knowledge. It is very common for a TV journalism graduate not to have used a camera during his/her study. However, with internet spreading, mainly through mobile telephones, new opportunities for improving the quality of journalism and increasing/strengthening freedom of expression have developed. Professionalism is poorly developed. Independent media are continually under threat of being arrested. Salaries are low and brown envelope journalism widespread. Mainstream media hardly report on any developments outside of the country’s capital and they also largely ignore women as an audience, not addressing issues that are important to them. Gender–based violence and gender-based discrimination is rampant in the country, but little effort is made by media outlets to shed light on the growing gender divide. There are very few influential female journalists. Recent developments are the licensing of several community radio stations, which are all aligned to the state. The announcement of the digitisation process, which has been delayed, comes with high expectations. It remains to be seen how and if this will change the current state of affairs. Gender is an underdeveloped segment in the sector. Apart from the women's glossy Jewel, there are virtually no women-centered and gender balanced content. Her Zimbabwe is still there, but its activity has been minimal.

EJC and FPU have both been active in Zimbabwe in recent years through MFSII funding. EJC collaborated with the Thomson Reuters Foundation since 2011 to establish The Source. Key accomplishments include: launching and initiating an independent financial and business news service and nation-wide stringer network; providing technical consulting on designing the operational model and IT infrastructure, training, recruitment and mentoring of business journalists and stringers; distribution of stories into national media; and providing legal support and indemnity insurance.

STRATEGY L&A FPU/EJC: Through its partnerships with The Source and MCZ will support lobby and advocacy activities on the restrictive media environment and increasing government accountability, access to information and open data, and citizen engagement in media platforms. In order to be successful, an additional partner(s) needs to be identified in the area of monitoring media freedom, freedom of expression and reporter safety. The media partners will cooperate closely with civil society groups to promote women empowerment in the country. STRATEGY FOR CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT FOR L&A EJC/FPU: Capacity development for lobby and advocacy of partners will focus on the following key themes: Strengthen capacity of partners to further expand content and open new platforms for syndicated news and advocacy commentary, launch an Investigative Bureau and sections focused on women- produced content and female audiences; Support and improve journalists’ role as civil society watchdogs by increasing their capacity to produce high-quality, ethical, data-driven investigative, financial and accountability reports and strengthen their capacity on safety & Internet security issues and use of secure whistle blower platforms; Support the ability of partners and their networks to effectively monitor press freedom/content quality/safety issues as part of their overall lobbying efforts directed toward appropriate government agencies and officials; Strengthen capacity of partners to interact and strategically integrate into pan-African media networks and to engage with local civil society advocacy partners such as Zimbabwe Editors Forum, Media Monitoring Project, Media Commission; Develop digital tools, training and media literacy activities in order increase overall citizen engagement in media, with particular focus on increasing the participation of women and youth; Provide citizen journalism training in order to equip journalists and (citizen) journalists with needed skills and tools to provide uncensored information and news throughout Zimbabwe. GENDER EQUALITY will be approached through two kinds of interventions: Increasing awareness among the boundary partner of the necessity of instituting gender policies and exploration of a developing a formal gender policy in order to ensure that current hiring practices, communications and all in-house materials/resources reflect gender sensitivity; Gender mainstreaming will be reflected in The Source content production on all levels: gender of reporters/stringers, sources of information and topics on gender will be emphasised and monitored. Specific safety/security situation of female journalist will be focused on. SAFETY ASPECTS will be approached through three kinds of interventions: Safety and security measures (physical and cyber) will be mainstreamed into internal policies as well as staff capacity building training materials; Safety/security matters will be internally monitored regularly and reported to a domestic and international audience; Safety/Security resources will be produced and utilised by all The Source staff.

title.narrative: Sustainability development: Media increasingly operate as efficient and self-sustaining organisations.

The Source is an independent, sustainable credible online news service in Zimbabwe that becomes a prime source of balanced, objective reporting on the country’s economy and its development for its citizens.

description.narrative: 2016: The Source is in the process of reconstituting its core journalism/editorial office as well as its national correspondents network; Two newly recruited staff are being trained in-house for duties at the Harare editorial offices and/or deployment to the field; The overhaul of the Source’s web and visibility presence is underway in partnership with SourceFabric. It is expected to provide an end-to-end news production, curation and distribution platform as well as live blogging of events in real time. 2017: The Source is in the process of hiring a full time IT/visibility officer as part of The Source's relaunch of its website, content management system, news production/curation/distribution platform and live blog guided by technical expertise from SourceFabric. On-going discussions with news agency for utilisation of The Source content at the pan-African level. The Source advanced towards launching Super Desk, a content management system, which allows The Source to manage and co-ordinate its workflow better, linking core staff at head office in Harare with correspondents across Zimbabwe. A MoU was signed between The Source African News Agency (ANA), which will distribute the Source's content free of charge for 6 months. The Source is in the process of recruiting a Digital Manager, who will co-ordinate the news agency's digital products and platforms. Superdesk, a customised content management system designed specifically for The Source, officially launched in June which allows Source editorial staff to manage and increase the quality/quantity of content output across various digital platforms. Superdesk is a key tool of the Source’s overall strategy to increase audience as well as content offerings for potential subscribers. There is an increased uptake of The Source content, most notably by two privately owned weeklies: The Zimbabwe Independent and The Standard. The Superdesk newsroom management system is up and running utilised currently and exclusively by the editor-in-chief. Plans to bring expert in October to help retrain staff on content management system usage. Google analytics shows that the number of unique visitors to The Source website has increased three-fold between April and September this year to 75,000 page views. The story pick-ups in the print media are too numerous to count. The Source hired a Digital Products Programmer who will be responsible for selling subscriptions to media outlets and who will perform regular maintenance on Superdesk.

comment.narrative: Long-term sustainability is a key focus. There is a need to broaden their donor portfolio and develop efficient PME systems. The Source will focus on development of other donor sources, conduct audience research and build its audience in order to attract advertisers as well as subscribers. This will form the core of its overall strategic business plan taking into account the harsh Zimbabwean economic climate. The Source will begin the first steps toward implementation of a new efficient end-to-end news production, curation and distribution platform.

title.narrative: Mobile Community Zimbabwe enables citizen reporters and CSOs to produce content that advocate for social change and accountability using mobile applications and social media.

description.narrative: A small group of 10 citizen journalists, consisting of 6 alumni and 4 new people, has been trained in Q1 to form the nucleus of an MZC stringer network that will produce content regularly. They have started to produce reports. Next to this a smaller group of students will be trained in Q3 from which only the best ones will be offered to string for MCZ. Other trainings to NGO's will be done on request of when an opportunity to do so arises. A follow up training took place in Q2 of a small group of 10 citizen journalists, consisting of 6 alumni and 4 new people. After the first training held in Q1 a content planner and video editor were added to the local MCZ team. The training was both a form of induction for the two new team members as well as for the contributors to get acquainted and establish a working routine. By end of Q2 MCZ started to have a more stable production routine, is delivering 3 reports a week at set days and times. A majority of the reports are on issues related to the current economic hardship and ways of survival by ordinary citizens. In addition, reports have been produced attempting to tackle the confusion around the biometric voter registration system, as well as elections and role of youth. In Q3 a training in Public Social Accountability Monitoring took place for a small group of MCZ alumni and contributors, as part of the overall capacity building plan for 2017. It is the third capacity building training of this year. The overall objective was to introduce them to social monitoring concepts and practices and how to do this through citizen journalism. The effect of this has been reflected in more consistent production flow, and a focus on stories about social issues. By Q4 a large number of trained contributors no longer produced for MCZ as a many of them actually found employment with other media or pursued careers as freelancers for other outlets thanks to their training provided by this project, which is a positive outcome overall. However, this positive outcome is on the one hand negatively impacting the achievement of the strategic goals as set out in the strategic plan for 2017-2018, which become more difficult to realise as trained capacity goes away.

title.narrative: Mobile Community Zimbabwe effectively works together with local tertiary institutions and their network of young journalists in training-and mentoring citizen journalists.

description.narrative: MCZ already collaborates with 4 local universities through which young students are trained in citizen journalism using mobile phones. The new strategy foresees this partnership with universities to continue and the establishment of a winter and/or summer school to be hosted at and by one of the participating universities. New universities will be added per request. Winter school is planned for quarter 3. This remains the same in Q3. As indicated in earlier reports, the partnership with universities continues, which in July of 2017 materialised in MCZ holding the inaugural Winterschool, consisting of a 5-day training, held at the Midlands State University (MSU) whereby a total of 14 students (of which 8 are female) were instructed in the basics of mobile journalism. They are currently undergoing their mentorship. Reports produced during the mentorship and that are thought to be of a sufficient journalistic quality, are posted on the project's social media. This remains the same in Q4. However, the production level of this yearś student group was nevertheless lower than expected. Out of the 14 students trained, only four successfully completed the requisite 8 stories by the end of the extended mentoring period. 112 stories in total were the expected output. However, in the period under review, the students had produced only 65. The general under-performance of students was attributable to several factors including: the fact that the work students had to produce for the project sometimes conflicted with their classes and assignments. Out of the 65 stories produced by students, a total of 23 stories have been published and broadcast. From the lecturers’ feedback there are indications that the Universities recognise MCZ as a competent complimentary training institution.

title.narrative: Mobile Community Zimbabwe effectively works together with CSOs to distribute content to offline audiences.

description.narrative: There were some meetings held, and possibilities of content distribution discussed. Majority of CSOs have indicated that distribution poses certain risks, and are reluctant. There is one media organisation that reacted positively, yet the details still need to be worked out. Q4: Where distribution by CSOs is concerned, the situation remains unchanged. CSOs feel this could pose a risk and are reluctant to do so, even though they are positive towards work of MCZ. But other initiatives do take place where MCZ interacts and works together with other CSOs. Such as a social media and roundtable discussion hosted by the Swedish Embassy in October, on the opportunities and challenges for using social media as a vehicle for civil society networking, activism and civic engagement. MCZ also participated and made a presentation at the ZACRAS radio symposium held in November, on the subject of alternative publishing platforms in a digitally complex environment.

title.narrative: Media professionals acquire specific sector knowledge and capacity to work as effective reporters utilising innovative, multimedia and data-based techniques.

description.narrative: Finalisation of February 2017 capacity building activities for The Source correspondents network with focus on financial news reporting, ethics and gender, training of Source staff on utilisation of new content management system and Live Blog. Implementation of five-day business and financial news capacity building workshop for 15 The Source staff and correspondents. The workshop included sessions dedicated to reporting on gender, ethics, utilising innovative online tools and resources and local sources of data. This workshop took place in Harare on 06-10 February 2017. The Source senior staff continued to be trained on Superdesk, the new content management system. In May senior Source staff participated in five days of pre-launch content management system training for Superdesk, In May senior Source staff participated in consultations for ‘Sourcebot’, a new interactive newsbot designed to reach The Source’s audience via FB messenger. Production of the Sourcebot has moved from planning to actual coding of the software. The bot front end is being finished up (i.e. everything the users will interact with menus, quick responses, making sense of user questions etc.) then work starts on the building the corpus of articles that will be surfaced by Sourcebot. We expect the bot to go live by end of 2017. Preparations for workshop on Data Driven Journalism skills building and practical reportage outputs utilising data for publication for The Source staff and correspondents. In November The Source held an advanced Data and Financial Reporting Workshop with 16 staff members and stringers. There is an increased appreciation of data in stories, mainly from staff who now produce data tables to back up their stories but the problem remains with stringers. The use of Superdesk newsroom management system is now universal. In October staff was retrained and the new Digital Products Programmer was brought up to speed. Work continues on Sourcebot. The experimental bot is available. The Source Editor-In-Chief was part of the participants at the Bloomberg African Media Innovators programme held in Accra, Ghana from November 12-14, 2017. The conference provided an insight on how some African media houses are innovating to stay ahead of the curve.

description.narrative: A 2-day workshop was held 21-22 November in Harare for 21 Zimbabwean reporters, editors and publishers on the issues and overcoming the constraints of reporting on women and minority communities in Zimbabwean media. Journalists came from leading online/offline, independent/state-owned radio, TV and print outlets from Harare, Bulawayo and Zvishavane. Speakers and trainers represented different minority communities in Zimbabwe and discussions focused on how journalists can find ways of collaboration with CSOs for sources of stories and sources of information on social issues of diversity in Zimbabwe. A networking event took place 22 November in Harare for over 50 CSO reps and journalists which included discussions on reporting diversity issues in Zimbabwean media, the role CSOs can play, and breaking down barriers/misconceptions around these issues between the civil society and media communities. Outcomes have included collaborative stories published in December with more expected in Q1 2019 Carey Institute non-fiction fellows: Grace Mutandwa, a Zimbabwean journalist since the mind-1980s, was selected to attend a non-fiction book writing fellowship at the Carey Institute in New York state for five weeks in October-November 2018. She received daily on-site mentoring and coaching for her non-fiction book focused on the trials and pains of navigating daily life under the Mugabe regime: the intersection of social and political life. The book is expected to be published in in mid-2019.

The Source journalists/correspondents regularly produce impactful, well researched, balanced high-visibility journalism reportages and editorials that focus on Zimbabwe’s economy and the overall socio-economic development of the country.

description.narrative: The Source output currently averages approximately 10 stories per day with a visible and growing social media presence along with accompanying audience engagement and interaction. A daily digital news summary was launched in March 2017 for The Source subscribers. Via its daily news digest of over 20,000 subscribers, active Twitter and FB accounts and Whatsapp groups, The Source regularly engages with its audience whose feedback loops into editorial and content decisions. With Zimbabwe’s elections scheduled for 2018, The Source is getting the political economy into the national arena, with a series of features to stimulate debate around the economy and politics. The Source’s regular features and special reports are making the public aware of issues as they arise: This government response: http://source.co.zw/2017/09/panicked-zim-govt-threatens-to-clamp-down-on-social-media-says-economy-in-sound-shape/ was a direct response to The Source public query here: http://source.co.zw/2017/09/letter-to-minister-chombo-we-have-reason-to-panic/ http://source.co.zw/2017/09/opinion-currency-crisis-art-deception/ http://source.co.zw/2017/10/chinamasa-from-treasury-czar-to-policing-social-media/. Q4: The Source has become a leader in Zimbabwean media landscape, with its regular features and special reports keeping ahead of the story and raising public awareness of issues. They averaged two features/special reports per week. In November, one of The Source’s accountability features, was quoted by the ruling ZANU-PF MPs as a prime example of rampant corruption in former president Robert Mugabe’s government. http://source.co.zw/2016/05/special-report-zimbabwe-hands-600mln-energy-contracts-to-dodgy-dealers/. Q2 2018: The Source has increased coverage of business/economic topics in the reporting period linked to the upcoming 30 July Presidential election. This includes reporting on candidates' platforms as they relate to the economy, investment and trade.

title.narrative: Mobile Community Zimbabwe actively keeps track of stories according to a defined system/method (Stories to Learn) and promotes the stories that reflect social change

description.narrative: There are over 300 stories posted on the MCZ Facebook, website and youtube. In addition, MCZ attempts to harvest the stories that have led to social change through The Stories to Learn methodology, which was introduced by FPU. Via this method the first stories of impact of MCZ's distributed content were obtained. It is planned that this methodology will be regularly used in the future. This methodology has unveiled examples of stories that have had impact on the local level, whereby local authorities picked up a few of the stories in which MCZ’s citizen journalists addressed specific social problems. Based on these items the authorities made the necessary adjustments to solve the addressed problem. In Q2 10 stories were produced and published. Following the strategic planning in 2016 it was agreed that MCZ should next to training also venture into production. The operational stem is to publish at least three stories per week, which mean in one quarter, a total of at least 30 original stories are to be produced. What gets published is only what has been deemed to meet journalistic quality criteria. MCZ has been introduced to the methodology of Stories to Learn in 2016, which was well received. But it remains to be seen how the methodology will be incorporated by MCZ as a way also to find stories of social impact. On average MCZ produces 12 stories per month. Most are on social issues. In the period under review MCZ lost a few contributors, due to which some of the production slowed down. But once a new group was trained, the pace was regained. In Q4 25 stories were produced. Most are on social issues. A story on homosexuality in Bulawayo even went viral and had over 7.000 views.

title.narrative: MCZ operates according to an effective (digital) security plan

description.narrative: Digital security is included in MCZ's operational plan. MCZ's coordinator is a digital security expert. However, there is still need to devise a plan that also takes other threats into account. To be done in Q4.

title.narrative: MCZ registered locally

description.narrative: In order to register MCZ, different legal entities were explored in November and December 2016. Based on the findings of this inquiry it was agreed that MCZ would register as a Trust. Registration process has not been initiated yet and has been put on hold. Will follow only once adequate candidates as trustees are found. Q4: Registration process was dropped. Other alternatives to that are explored.

title.narrative: MCZ’s training curriculum incorporates module on both physical and digital safety and security

description.narrative: MCZ curriculum already incorporates a module on physical and digital safety. This module is updated annually with the latest news and trends on digital security as one of the employees is a digital security trainer. The physical safety is mentioned and curriculum advices on what not to do or how to avoid physical threats, yet it remains difficult in a context where journalists are harassed even when they are licensed, which makes the threat for citizen reporters even bigger. By concentrating on human interest stories and keep close to what and whom citizen reporters know, MCZ tries to diminish the threat.

title.narrative: The Source operates according to an effective (digital) security plan

description.narrative: The Source is working closely with Sourcefabric to securitise all of The Source's digital content and equipment. The Source has an annual website security and mitigation package for daily site back-ups. This would allow minimal disruptions and quick recovery should the site be attacked, hacked or closed down for any reason.

title.narrative: The Source capacity building curriculum incorporates components on both physical and digital safety and security.

description.narrative: The Source's workshop included a module on physical and digital safety and security for its correspondents (Harare, 06-10 February 2017).

title.narrative: Mobile Community Zimbabwe acts internally according to an organisation-wide gender policy

description.narrative: MCZ, though only a project, has a high focus on gender equality in both its daily operations as well as productions. It further adheres to local gender policies despite not having its own document.

title.narrative: The Source is aware of gender equality and implements this in their organisation.

description.narrative: The Source’s office manager is an alumnus of ‘Women in News’ and is undergoing a one-year WIN media training programme at Wits University, Johannesburg, South Africa. The Source staff, including interns, has a 50:50 composition. On December 19, The Source, in conjunction with Gender and Media Connect, an NGO, held a workshop on gender balancing in story writing.
